repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit (SAC II) Project in Sao Tome and Principe
            were as follows: overall outcome of the project was rated
            unsatisfactory, project sustainability was unlikely, and the
            performance of the Bank and the Borrower was rated
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project are: (i)
            political stability and sustained government commitment are
            essential. The "stop-go" approach in the
            implementation of SAC II and the resulting delays can be
            clearly linked to the prevailing political climate combined
            with weak human resources; (ii) Flexibility in program
            implementation is necessary to respond to evolving, fragile
            situations, performance criteria should be tailored to suit
            country-specific conditions with close Bank supervision;
            (iii) reliance on a single commodity for economic growth can
            impair longer-term stability, even with temporary adjustment
            aided by donors; and (iv) structural measures in the absence
            of macroeconomic stability are unlikely to have a
            significant impact. The experience of SAC II illustrates
            clearly the dependence between a sound macroeconomic
            framework and the response to structural measures, even when
            appropriately designed and implemented. In such cases, even
            when specific conditionality's are met, careful thought
            should be given to invoking the general conditionality
            related to macroeconomic performance.

repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Second Phase of the
            Structural Adjustment Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Structural Adjustment Credit
            supports phase two of the Government's structural
            adjustment program for the period 1990-1992. The thrust of
            this phase is: (a) to consolidate progress in exchange rate,
            fiscal, and monetary policy; (b) to stimulate economic
            growth through appropriate trade and pricing policies, and
            land redistribution; (c) to rationalize the public
            investment program; (d) to improve the administrative
            capacity of the public sector through public enterprise and
            civil service reform; (e) to improve the functioning of the
            financial system; and (f) to manage the exernal debt burden
            with the view to freeing up resources for economic growth.
            The program will continue to focus on improved incentives
            for production of traded goods within a stable macroeconmic
            framework. It also includes a technical assistance component
            primarily geared to support institutional reform.
